product_context.title: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: I've bought 12 TP-Link smart light switches over the past 3-4 years. Two weeks ago, one just stopped working. I figured, okay, stuff happens. But then—boom—another one dies the following week. The day after that? A third one goes out. That’s three failures in under two weeks. Out of curiosity, I checked TP-Link’s website. Surprise, surprise: the warranty is only 1–2 years. Guess what? All three failed right after the warranty expired. These things aren’t defective — they’re engineered to fail once you’re no longer covered. That’s not a coincidence. That’s a planned-obsolescence scam. These smart switches are not “smart”—they’re a stupid waste of money. Regular light switches last 10–20 years, while these overpriced plastic toys can’t even last two. DO NOT BUY these switches. I don’t care how fancy the app is or what brand it is — TP-Link or otherwise. If it needs replacing every couple of years, it’s trash. Stick with old-school switches. They’re cheap, reliable, and they don’t leave you in the dark — literally.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2025
reviews.title: TP-Link Smart Switches Are Garbage – Built to Break, Total Scam

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: I have several of these dimmable smart switches throughout the house, unfortunately the quality is sub-part after experiencing several failures within the first year of use. The issue is that the switch fails to energize the load (connected device/light). It powers on fine, has network connectivity, and can be interacted with via smart device apps, but it doesn't turn on the light. A test with a multi-meter confirms that it fails to actually energize the connection, so the problem isn't downstream from the switch. Online searches confirm this seems to be a common issue with TP-Link switches where the internal relay fails which results in the described issue. I contacted company support who didn't give me any issues with RMA'ing the product, but there's one serious problem. You have to pay to ship them the defective unit... I went to my UPS store with the product packaged & boxed, but the cost to ship was more than the cost of the switch on Amazon, making it not worth the money to RMA because it would be cheaper to just buy another unit than replace the failed one. Because of this scenario, TP-Link is now off of my list for Smart Home devices and all future purchases will be another brand, even if more expensive.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2025
reviews.title: Not worth the return shipping

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: Have used this HS220 smart switch for about 9 months and experienced it randomly powered off 5-6 times. The mobile app could still connect to the switch, but no commands would turn the light back on. After a few hours, the switch would recover on its own. When it happened again recently, I contacted TP-Link support. The rep quickly acknowledged a known issue with the product and offered a replacement. However, their Standard RMA process requires you to pay for return shipping, wait for them to process the return (3-5 days after receipt), and then they will send out a replacement, leaving you without a switch for weeks. The Advanced RMA options cost $25-$50, much more then the price of a new switch on Amazon. Frustrated by this poor warranty service, I’ve decided to avoid TP-Link products entirely. I’m going to return a recently purchased TP-Link wireless router within its return period, despite it having no issues so far.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2025
reviews.title: defect product with poor warranty service

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: I rarely write reviews, but my experience with TP-Link was so frustrating that I had to speak up and warn others. I bought a brand-new TP-Link smart switch that turned out to be defective. When I contacted support, they required me to remove the switch and ship it back first at my own expense. Only after they receive it will they send a replacement—and they don’t even confirm whether it will be new, used, or refurbished. This process has dragged on for over 20 days, and it’s still not resolved. TP-Link responds to emails once a day, and every time I try to explain the situation, I just get the same generic response. I’ve explained multiple times that removing the switch without having a replacement is unsafe for my kids, but they simply don’t care. All I asked for was a replacement to be sent first along with a prepaid return label. This is standard practice with many companies that value their customers—but not TP-Link. At this point, the cost of returning the switch is almost the same as buying a new one. It’s ridiculous. I’ve wasted weeks dealing with their support and still have no resolution. I’m done with TP-Link. Their support is slow, unhelpful, and inconsiderate. I will never buy from them again and I strongly encourage others to stay far away. Spend a little more with a company that actually backs their products and treats customers with respect.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2025
reviews.title: Terrible Warranty Experience – Stay Away from TP-Link Products

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: Let me tell you, this "smart" dimmer switch is about as smart as a brick. I've spent more time wrestling with its "local access only" error than I have actually enjoying dimmed lighting. I'm starting to think "local access" is Kasa's fancy way of saying "you're stuck with a glorified on/off switch." "Works with Alexa and Google Home," they said. "Seamless integration," they promised. Lies! All lies! I've reset this thing more times than I've had hot dinners. I've unplugged, replugged, danced a ritualistic jig around my router, and still, it mocks me with its "local access only" message. Need a neutral wire? Fine, I get it. But apparently, you also need the patience of a saint and the technical prowess of a NASA engineer to get this thing to work properly. I'm tech-savvy, and this switch has me ready to throw it through a window. Forget about remotely controlling your lights. Forget about setting schedules. Forget about impressing your friends with your "smart home." You'll be too busy cursing Kasa and wondering why you didn't just stick with a dumb, reliable switch. UL Certified? More like UL-timately frustrating. No hub required? More like a hub of endless headaches. Save yourself the trouble and buy something else. Anything else. This switch is a monument to wasted time and shattered expectations. If I could give it zero stars, I would.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2025
reviews.title: One Star - A Masterclass in Frustration

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: I just love these switches!! I decided to add a few more to my home, however I had difficulty pairing it to my network. I kept getting a "Pairing Failure" notification. I have a not had a problem in the past until now. I followed every suggestion to no avail. Even uninstalled/reinstalled the Kasa app and restarted my router multiple times. I changed out the switch thinking it was defective. I decided to try pairing a Smart Plug to rule out my router and had no issues. I finally called tech support and Jonathan R was super helpful and patient! It was a simple fix; turn off Mobile Data. BINGO! I guess that suggestion should be offered in the "Pairing Failure" notification. Not sure why it only impacted the switch and not the plug install.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on March 2, 2025
reviews.title: Great switches, pairing was a bit problematic

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: I purchased a large number of KASA smart switches for my new home, and have generally been satisfied with their operation. Unfortunately, one of the HS220 switches recently failed, after having functioned normally for about 14 months. Once the switch stopped working, the switch itself appeared normal - with the circular light on the switch turning on and off as the switch was depressed. The switch, however, no longer turned the attached 2 LED ceiling lights on or off via any of the 3 modes: depressing the switch, via the KASA App on my phone or via voice commands (Alexa). Resetting the switch did not correct the problem, nor did turning power off at the breaker panel for ~1 minute. Once removed, the body of the switch showed no signs of discoloration that might suggest that any of the internal circuitry had overheated. In contacting KASA for replacement of the switch under their 2-year warranty, I was given various options to return the defective switch - all of which requiring me to spend at least $14.99 (or much more) to replace the failed switch for which I paid $14.96 for when new. The current price for a new HS220 switch on Amazon is $16.99. Since KASA was unwilling to simply provide a no-cost return shipping label, I purchased a new HS220 switch from Amazon, and the new switch is operating normally. I sincerely hope that the remaining 20+ KASA smart switches that I have installed do not exhibit such failures, as I would like to continue to utilize switches from a single manufacturer to simplify operation of my "smart" home. It is unfortunate that KASA has little interest in obtaining failed, lower price items (such as switches), both to permit them to understand the root cause of such fails and to retain customer satisfaction and loyalty.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2025
reviews.title: KASA Warranty Concern

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: I ordered an had a licensed electrician install multiple smart switches and smart dimmer switches from Kasa. All but one of the switches quickly and efficiently connected to my WiFi network and are working fine. One switch, the HS220 one-way dimmer switch works perfectly manually, but refuses to connect with the WiFi network. I reached out to their tech support team via email (the only option). Over the course of nearly a week, they repeatedly asked me for the same information and never tried to fix the problem. My only resort was to return the switch to Amazon, and obtain and install a new one. Hopefully, that one will work. So, my rating for the peoducts is between 4vans 5 stars. My rating for T-link customer service and tech support is 0 stars. They will waste your time and energy needlessly.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2025
reviews.title: Product great (when it works), tech support sucks

reviews.text: I bought 2 of these identical units in one purchase. One of them worked as it should, the other one does not connect to wifi and just blinks red. I emailed for suppot, and the Mfr Support asked for a ridiculous amount of information, then didn't respond. Here's the info they asked, despite me sending the amazon invoice showing I bought 2 of them: TP-Link ID App Version Model and OS of phone Model and Brand of the Router Screenshot of error message, if any. What is the LED status of the device? Please provide Picture of the S/N and hardware version of your device on its back label or on the box. Kindly send us a receipt or invoice for the device, including details such as the name of the store, unit name/price, and date of purchase. These are both hard-wired into my house, so taking a picture of the back will require the electrician to come back out. If you are going to purchase these, take pictures before they are installed, otherwise you're SOL.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2025
reviews.title: Failure out of box, will not connect to wifi.

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: Quick installation guide HAS NOTHING ON HOW TO WIRE THE PRODUCT. There is no manual or support to tell you how to wire the product. Just how to set it up. I was replacing TREATLIFE Smart Light Switch, which took me 2 minutes to wire. App sucks, but light switch works. Took the Kasa TP link out and put the Treatlife back in. It took 30 seconds to wire the Treatlife in. All wires are color-coded. Kasa TP link 2 wires and unlabled screws. Might be awesome but I'll never know, Sending it back
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2025
reviews.title: Until I hire an electrician, I'll never know if it works. Sending back!

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: I have several smart switches but they aren’t this brand. Got this one because the I have the WiFi extender. Well the switch itself works but it won’t reset to connect to my WiFi. So now I guess I have to buy another. It won’t be this brand again.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2025
reviews.title: Won’t connect

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: Works well with echo devices
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2025
reviews.title: Works very well with older home wiring

reviews.productTitle: Kasa Smart Dimmer Switch HS220, Single Pole, Needs Neutral Wire, 2.4GHz Wi-Fi Light Switch Works with Alexa and Google Home, UL Certified, No Hub Required, 1 Pack
reviews.text: I can't stress how much I hate this switch. I don't want to use a secondary China made and likely monitored app to control a simple switch. Once I wire in a switch I want to be using it in 15 to 20 seconds, not looking to reinvent the wheel. Super disappointed and by the way I'm not disconnecting my VPN either TPLINK. I wouldn't do it for a country I trust, much less the PRC.
reviews.date: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2025
reviews.title: Useless piece of Chinese made junk...
